data.title: Unable to start debugger with "/bin/bash --login"
data.body:
Dear All,

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 17.04
- Language : Ruby

# Steps to Reproduce:

### Background: 
I have installed "ruby on rails" using RVM, after that, I could only use the integrated terminal after running the command **"/bin/bash --login"** i.e. to run in a login shell. and I am also able to config the same in **settings.json** by modifying _"terminal.integrated.shellArgs.linux": ["--login"]_
### Issue: 
now when start the debug with **Rails server** option. I am getting error **Debugger terminal error: Process failed: spawn rdebug-ide ENOENT**. unable to understand what this is and how to fix. Please help... I guess this is also down to **shell login**

Best Regards!!
Ravi

data.title: 'Selected error' highlighting color is not covered by themes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Apply dark-styled theme.
2.  Build project with some errors in it.
3.  Open "Problems window".
4.  Click on one of the problems to make problematic line of code highlighted.
5.  Struggle to find where that highlighting is.

Example (line 23 is highlighted):
![dark_highlight](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4990494/25867762/44ad6e88-3503-11e7-89eb-392557bd7209.PNG)

That colors doesn't seem to be hard-coded somewhere since it's different in light-styled themes:

![light-highlight](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4990494/25867849/90858e62-3503-11e7-849b-923bff551a98.PNG)

Or in a Red theme:
![red-highlight](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4990494/25867859/99cb7f0e-3503-11e7-9266-10ed893cfac3.PNG)

I believe that this color should be customizable by theme files.

Workaround: according to [this question](http://stackoverflow.com/a/43875845/1823524) it is customizable with "Custom CSS and JS" extension with custom css entry named "rangeHighlight". 

[Wiki](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Editor-decorations-&-colors) mentions setting with the same name, however it seem to correspond to something different.

data.title: Go to definition fails when maxNodeModuleJsDepth = 0
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: OS X

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code in a new workspace
2. `npm init -y`
3. `npm install --save express`
4. In `tsconfig.json`:
```json
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es6",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "allowJs": true,
        "checkJs": true,
        "noEmit": true,
        "maxNodeModuleJsDepth": 0
    },
    "exclude": [
        "node_modules"
    ]
}
```
5. In `index.js`: 
```js
const express = require('express')
```

6. Right click on `'express'`, and choose *Go to definition*

### Expected behaviour: 

The editor navigates to the .js file containing the module implementation (under node_modules/express)

### Actual behaviour: 

The editor says 

> No definition found for 'express'

- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|angular2-snippets|danwahlin|1.0.15|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.4|
|Angular1|johnpapa|0.1.16|
|Angular2|johnpapa|2.2.3|
|mssql|ms-mssql|1.0.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.9.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.12.2|
|team|ms-vsts|1.117.2|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.1|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.6.0|
|vscode-gulp|tanato|0.0.4|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code Insiders
2. Open File and select open folder (OR alternatively open a folder you were already working with)

**Expected**
3. SRC folder is still part of your explorer tree

**Actual**:
3. "SRC" folder has desapeared

**Comment:** Usually new features are well advertised with the top notification bar and a learn more or other actions buttons to activate. In the few machines I have recently updated/installed VS Code Insiders,  I have not seen such notifications/warnings.

Thanks, and hope that helps for that feature or future new features.

Dan

data.title: Go to implementation should navigate to .js file instead of typescript type definitions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: OS X

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code in a new workspace
2. `npm init -y`
3. `npm install --save express`
4. `npm install --save-dev @types/express`
5. In `tsconfig.json`:
```json
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es6",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "allowJs": true,
        "checkJs": true,
        "noEmit": true,
        "maxNodeModuleJsDepth": 1
    },
    "exclude": [
        "node_modules"
    ]
}
```
6. In `index.js`: 
```js
const express = require('express')
```

7. Right click on `'express'`, and choose *Go to implementation*

### Expected behaviour: 

The editor navigates to the .js file containing the module implementation (under node_modules/express)

### Actual behaviour: 

The editor navigates to the installed **express** type definitions

data.title: Code Folding won't be remembered after latest update. (fixes #26157)
data.body:
This is a fix for #26157 intended to be pushed to the recovery release. 

Issue (original):
* open an editor
* keep some view state (folding, cursors, scroll position)
* close the editor
* reopen the editor
=> view state is lost

Issue (variant):
* make sure tab preview is enabled (it is by default)
* open an editor
* keep some view state (folding, cursors, scroll position)
* open another editor
* go back to the previous editor
=> view state is lost

We always store the view state of files when you switch between editors or when you close and come back to editors (persisted in local storage). The bug happened during last milestone because the way we dispose resources changed.

Previously:
* close an editor
* persist view state from the editor model
* dispose editor model

Now:
* close an editor
* dispose editor model
* persist view state from editor model
=> since the model is disposed, the view state is undefined

My fix introduces a new event `onWillCloseEditor` directly on the stacks model which the text file editor can use to persist the view state right before the model goes away. On top of that we also only persist the view state when the input is not disposed, because otherwise we still hit the current issue that we try to persist the view state of a disposed model.

@Tyriar can you check the code and let me know what you think? If you guys want to move ahead and release recovery today, feel free to merge. Otherwise I can do it tomorrow.

data.title: Ask to replace dirty file when opening it again explicitly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. put a file in a folder
2. open it with right click -> open with VSCode
3. in VS code, just modify the file
4. in the explorer, update the content of the file (i.e. a log file)
5. open it with right click -> open with VSCode
6. VSCode does not replace the old one by the new one

I understand that the first file is modified and thus the "close" is blocked is the user does not save or undo, but is there a way to ignore that, especially when I replace it by the same file (=same path ?) or a duplicated tab

thanks

data.title: Code Folding won't be remembered after latest update. (fixes #26157)
data.body:
This is a fix for #26157 intended to be pushed to the recovery release. 

Issue (original):
* open an editor
* keep some view state (folding, cursors, scroll position)
* close the editor
* reopen the editor
=> view state is lost

Issue (variant):
* make sure tab preview is enabled (it is by default)
* open an editor
* keep some view state (folding, cursors, scroll position)
* open another editor
* go back to the previous editor
=> view state is lost

We always store the view state of files when you switch between editors or when you close and come back to editors (persisted in local storage). The bug happened during last milestone because the way we dispose resources changed.

Previously:
* close an editor
* persist view state from the editor model
* dispose editor model

Now:
* close an editor
* dispose editor model
* persist view state from editor model
=> since the model is disposed, the view state is undefined

My fix introduces a new event `onWillCloseEditor` directly on the stacks model which the text file editor can use to persist the view state right before the model goes away. On top of that we also only persist the view state when the input is not disposed, because otherwise we still hit the current issue that we try to persist the view state of a disposed model.

@Tyriar can you check the code and let me know what you think? If you guys want to move ahead and release recovery today, feel free to merge. Otherwise I can do it tomorrow.

data.title: Linux: commands with keybindings ignore when clause of the command if defined

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Version: 1.12.1
OS: Windows 10

I have the following keybinding:

```json
    {
        "key": "ctrl+enter",
        "command": "workbench.action.toggleZenMode",
        "when": "editorTextFocus"
    }
```

When I am using `git` and I am entering a commit message, by pressing <kbd>ctrl+enter</kbd> to commit the message, the editor commits it but it also goes into zen mode. Based on my `when` statement, it shouldn't do that since I am using `editorTextFocus`.

data.title: Support arbitrary data to be looped from one debug session to a restarted session
data.body:
I noticed that we sometimes have to hardcode a "port" in a launch config if we want to use the same port in restarted debug sessions. Here is an example from the MERN Starter Recipe (see https://github.com/weinand/vscode-recipes/tree/master/MERN-Starter):

```json
"protocol": "inspector",
"runtimeExecutable": "nodemon",
"runtimeArgs": [
    "--inspect=9222"
],
"port": 9222,
"restart": true,    
```

The ugly thing about this is the redundancy (and potential inconsistency) between the `protocol`, `runtimeArgs`, and `port` attributes. If the value of `protocol` is changed to `legacy`, the values for `runtimeArgs` and `port` must be changed as well, otherwise a problematic inconsistency will occur.

It would be preferable if we could just use this:
```json
"protocol": "inspector",
"runtimeExecutable": "nodemon",
"restart": true,    
```

In this case the debug adapter picks a random port and passes it with the correct 'inspect' or 'debug' option to the runtime.

The problem is how this "port" can be looped from the DA back to VS Code and then to the next session. 

I suggest that we support a generic mechanism for passing arbitrary data from one debug session to the next by extending the type of the `restart`attribute of the `TerminatedRequest` from "boolean" to "any".

VS Code will loop this `restart` value unmodified and uninterpreted from one session to a restarted next session as the (already existing) `__restart` attribute of the `launchRequest`.

data.title: Refactor when moving files
data.body:
The best feature you could have is to refactor when moving files in the explorer (out of the box) 
There is a extension (move ts) but it's buggy. 
It's a basic refactor thing, which to my surprise is not in visual code. 

So if i move a file from a folder to another, i want it's path reference to be updated automatically in the project. I tried this on a angular 2 project with .ts files and it did not work. I haven't tried with other files.

Thanks

This works nicely in stable

data.title: Irrelevant snippet has precedence over user snippet?
data.body:
- VSCode Version:  1.12.1
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.12.4

I have a snippet called `clog`, which is an abbreviation for `console.log` that I've used for quite a while. Since the last version of vs code, however. It seems that the ranking for snippets has changed, and I'm getting an irrelevant suggestion as the first choice, and muscle memory makes me want to just press return to activate it.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/577144/25853592/44a3161a-34c5-11e7-9abf-b26c2448c68a.png)

I'm not sure where this suggestion comes from, it's nothing that I've typed in any of the files I have open. But I think that probably, user snippets should get precedence here. especially if they're this specific (I'm typing the exact and complete prefix).

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a javascript file
2. Create a snippet with the prefix "clog",
3. Somewhere in the file, type the word "clog" and see the suggestions appear
3. See alternative suggestions appear before manually added snippet

data.title: Select all (cmd+a) does not work in search box
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.12.1 (1.12.1)
- OS Version: OSX latest

When the search in file box is open, the key binding cmd+a to select all does not work.

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open search box (cmd+f)
2. Type in text
3. Press cmd+a and notice that the OS shortcut for select all does not work in the search box

### Background / Additional Info
If the search box already has focus, pressing cmd+f does not re-highlight the search phrase and I end up pasting/typing in another value when I wanted to replace the search term - It would be great to highlight search text any time cmd+f is pressed, even if already focused, in addition to allowing the standard OS shortcut to select all.

data.title: @font-face is not being syntax colored correctly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (c615b43be67170e166779c9020a249442c4f36fc, 2017-05-09T06:05:27.476Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|ng-template|Angular|0.1.3|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.7.0|
|sort-lines|Tyriar|1.2.0|
|Bookmarks|alefragnani|0.14.1|
|project-manager|alefragnani|0.16.0|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.4.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|vscode-html-css|ecmel|0.1.4|
|tslint|eg2|0.14.0|
|Angular2|johnpapa|2.2.3|
|vscode-icon-theme|jtlowe|1.5.0|
|theme-karyfoundation-themes|karyfoundation|11.1.0|
|HTMLHint|mkaufman|0.3.3|
|vscode-autoprefixer|mrmlnc|2.0.0|
|vscode-stylefmt|mrmlnc|2.3.0|
|angular2-inline|natewallace|0.0.17|
|typescript-hero|rbbit|0.12.0|
|project-snippets|rebornix|0.5.0|
|stylelint|shinnn|0.24.0|
|darcula-extended|smlombardi|3.3.2|
|slime|smlombardi|2.3.1|
|theme-tesla|smlombardi|6.0.0|
|change-case|wmaurer|1.0.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

In [my theme](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=smlombardi.slime), there is a global color set for 

````json
{
  "name": "Preprocessor At Rule",
	 "scope": "meta.preprocessor.at-rule keyword.control.at-rule, keyword.control.at-rule",
	"settings": {
		"foreground": "#8693A5"
	}
	}
````

but later in the file I set colors for more specific at rules such as 

````json
{
	"name": "SCSS at-Rule Mixin",
	"scope": "keyword.control.at-rule.mixin.scss",
	"settings": {
		"foreground": "#e78484"
	}
}
````

This works as expected, these are colored as `#e78484`.

However, @font-face is **not** being overridden and remains `#8693A5`:

![screen shot 2017-05-09 at 9 19 47 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/835148/25852984/30ffe506-3499-11e7-9b31-9cb5af9165dd.png)

despite the code being 

````json
{
	"name": "SCSS at-Rule FontFace",
	"scope": "keyword.control.at-rule.font-face.scss",
	"settings": {
		"foreground": "#e78484"
	}
},
{
	"name": "SCSS at-Rule FontFace at-sign",
	"scope": "keyword.control.at-rule.font-face.scss punctuation.definition.keyword.scss",
	"settings": {
		"foreground": "#AA6161"
	}
}
````

data.title: The front part of file paths on debug console are ignored
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:40:39.245Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-51-generic
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.7.0|
|theme-dracula|dracula-theme|1.15.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.14.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run `Start Debug`, which runs mocha tests and prints test results with file paths on `DEBUG CONSOLE`
![screenshot from 2017-05-09 21-31-48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7734590/25851206/d258171e-34ff-11e7-80d4-0645ef99fc1e.png)
2. Click a file path on `DEBUG CONSOLE`
![screenshot from 2017-05-09 21-40-12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7734590/25851269/1b3272fe-3500-11e7-9bf4-6d2ee6377f1b.png)

---

I think that the parser should search words backward after detecting a file path in debug console, so that it doesn't ignore the front part of relative paths. Currently the parser seems to only look forward when searching using regular expressions.

data.title: Files treeview control displays incorrect information when scrolling while adding a new file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a project with a complex folder/file structure, at least big enough to fill the files treeview.
2. Select a file of a subfolder.
3. Press the "New File" icon.
4. Instead of wrtting the file's name, scroll up or down until the new file is outside the boundaries of the control.

After doing this, the "New File" command is cancelled and the tree displays files inside incorrect folders until the application is restarted.

data.title: Provide insiders builds in a yum repo

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
At the moment the latest stable releases are being made available from a yum repo at:

*  https://packages.microsoft.com/yumrepos/vscode/

Really would be fantastic if the insider's build could also be made available in this way, from something like:

*  https://packages.microsoft.com/yumrepos/vscode-insiders/

From what I can see this is being done for Ubuntu, so why not RHEL7?

It would make the updating of the more frequent Insiders builds a lot easier than having to download them then install manually.

If you cannot provide a repo, then even a valid direct link that could be installed directly like:

* yum install http://..../code-insiders-...rpm

would be good - with the current re-directions it doesn't appear to be possible to get a valid URL to do this from the download page.

Thanks,

Darren.

data.title: regression in new IntelliSense sorting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12
- OS Version: any

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an extension with a snippet `do`
2. The extension should also supply different autocompletes containing the letters `d` and `o` (eg. `defoverridable`)
3. When typing `do` in a document, the first autocomplete item should (and used to) be the exact match (snippet `do`) instead the keyword autocomplete is the first item:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/311019/25850728/a30ede2a-34c3-11e7-82c0-c8be77a5fc3c.png)

This makes it very hard to use the elixir extension. Is there any way to work around this regression?

https://github.com/fr1zle/vscode-elixir/issues/64
